May it please yo
r
good L. being parted from
e
Hage,
w
t
e
Councel of state
e 4 of this
moneth, because o
r
voiage was by water,
and
e winde against us, we arrived not
heere till 5 daies after. We found the
approches made, and
e Artillerie prepa-
red, to beginne
e batterie as to day. But
the towne being summoned, after sundrie
sendinges too and fro, hath yelded this
evening, upon like composition as
Deventer
and
Zutphen,
but w
t
some litle alteration,
in regard of their privileges, w
ch
are more
ample then
e rest in other townes. They
have urged very earnestly to have
e use
of bothe religions: w
ch
would be graunted
by no meanes. Because it is late,
Count
Maurice
can not enter
e towne this evening:
but they have admitted 300 of o
r
souldiers,
and have taken order
at suche as were in
e towne, w
ch
were also 300 shall depart
to morowe morning: after whose departure
e gates shall be opened to
e Count.
We could not learne all this while, howe the
Enemie was affected for relieving
e towne.
There came to
e
Grave,
w
ch
is two leages of,
certaine troupes of horse and foote, to
e nomber
of 3000 as
e bruite is given, and under
e
conduct of
Verdugo.
But they have attempted
nothing upon us. I can not yet
signifie howe this campe shall be next imploied
fol.92v
But Count Maurice and
e martial commaun-
ders would willingly retire, and end this
sommer w
t
this hono
r
.
Count William
and
the
states of Frise
are bent towardes
Steen-
wicke
, and thinke it an exploit,
at will
be easely atchieved. When any thing is re-
solved, I will advertise yo
r
L. And be-
cause this bearer my brother hath bin w
t
me,
and hath seene what hath past at
e siege of
this towne: hath also taken a special viewe
of
e seate of
e place, and of every quarter
in
e campe, and can give yow
e platforme
draweng by himself, I shall have lesse occa-
sion to stay him from carieng these newes
to yo
r
L.
and therfore take my humble
leave. From
e shippes before Nieumeghen
